occurrences.line_text: When forward we should fare, he flat refused
Against her Knight, her gentlenesse refused,
They all refused in regard of her,
Then crauing sucke, and then the sucke refusing.
But he refusing him to let vnlace,
And reasons brought, that no man could refute;
So pure the mettall was, and well refynd,
Robs reason of her due regalitie
And Regan greater loue to him profest,
Without regard of armes and dreaded fight:
Great pleasure mixt with pittifull regard,
And not regard dew right and iust desarts?
Regard of worldly mucke doth fowly blend,
Others through friends, others for base regard;
O why should heauenly God to man haue such regard?
Withouten reason or regard. Well knew
But in good order, and with dew regard;
A sweet regard, and amiable grace,
He should aduaunced be to high regard,
Without regard of grace, or comely amenaunce.
That all regard of shame she had discust,
Onely for honour and for high regard,
Beates downe both leaues and buds without regard,
Yet therewith sore enrag'd, with sterne regard
But she thereto would lend but light regard,
The knight him seeing fly, had no regard
Through gracious regard of her faire eye,
With vigilant regard, and dew attent,
To him, without regard of gaine, or scath,
Vouchsafe with mild regard a wretches cace to heare.
And mou'd amisse with massie mucks vnmeet regard.
She in regard thereof him recompenst
And with their honours and their loues regard,
Without regard of good, dyes like ill grounded seeds.
With mild regard, to see his ruefull plight,
For his great iustice, held in high regard;
And thus vnto him spake, without regard or feare;
Empierced was with pittifull regard,
For such your kind regard, I can but rest your detter.
And with her ioyn'd Regard of womanhead;
Her fearefull speaches nought he did regard,
Did nought regard his malice nor his powre,
Without regard of pitty or of awe.
Did litle whit regard his courteous guize,
Yet she no whit his presents did regard,
She in regard hereof refusde and thought vnfit.
With such regard his sences rauished,
Yet like a Diamond of rich regard,
They all refused in regard of her,
But rends without regard of person or of time.
The resty raynes, regarded now no more:
For he regarded neither playnt nor teare,
To them, that list, these base regardes I lend:
That knowes no kinred, nor regardes no right,
And euermore when with regardfull sight
Whom nought regarding, they kept on their gate,
Who nought regarding her displeasure forward goth.
Regarding neither speare, that mote him slay,
Regarding more his faith, which he did plight,
And nought regarding her so goodly hew,
Regarding nought religion, nor their holy heast.
Regardlesse of that queane so base and vilde,
Regardlesse of her wounds, yet bleeding rife,
That many high regards and reasons gainst her red.
So when he had resigned his regiment,
Shalbe expird of Britons regiment.
Then loyall loue had royall regiment,
They two enough t'encounter an whole Regiment.
Gainst tortious powre and lawlesse regiment,
And old diuision into Regiments,
With fire and sword the region to inuade;
Through the wide region of the wastfull aire,
And eke all strangers in that region
Many great Regions are discouered,
In heauenly Registers aboue the Sunne,
And antique Registers for to auise,
She fell to ground for sorrowfull regret,
Whereat renfierst with wrath and sharpe regret,
Much greater griefe and shamefuller regret
Spake, as was meet, for ease of my regret:
By his faire patients side with sorrowfull regret.
I shortly will to you rehearse the same,
I no whit reck, ne you the like need to reherce.
Well knowing true all, that he did reherse,
Hearing him those same bloudy lines reherse;
But what I was, it irkes me to reherse
But what doe I their names seeke to reherse,
For aye the more that she the same reherst,
To captiue men, and make them all the world reiect.
But Coridon for cowherdize reiect,
Their wounds recur'd, and forces reincreast,
Which he perceiuing greatly gan reioice,
Doth not so much reioyce, as she reioyced theare.
And heauy heart with comfort doth reioyce.
She gan reioyce, and shew triumphant chere,
The whyles she wayld, the more they did reioyce.
And oft reioyce, and oft for wonder shout,
And much reioyced in their bloudy fray:
That euen heauen reioyced her sweete face to see.
Doth not so much reioyce, as she reioyced theare.
Which seene, he much reioyced in his cruell mind.
Reioyced at his miserable case,
The gentle knights reioyced much to heare
Ne lesse in hart reioyced Calidore,
Reioyced much to see his captiue plight,
Reioycing at the fall of that great beast,
He much reioyst, and courd it tenderly,
Both light of heauen, and strength of men relate:
Who all to her at large, as hapned, did relate.
And costly frame, were long here to relate.
To you I will not feare it to relate.
His long aduentures gan to him relate,
Mongst which, Serena did to him relate
Bynempt a sacred vow, which none should aye releace.
But since that band ye cannot now release,
And his foe fettred would release agayne,
And rather die then Ladies cause release.
As from my chiefest foe me to release,
But to release his former foule condition.
To hope for to release or mollify;
Released her, that else was like to sterue,
And he himselfe his right would eke releasse:
His rancorous despight did not releasse,
fayre Vna is releast:
From whose eternall bondage now they were releast.
Strikes in the stocke, ne thence can be rel[e]ast,
That shortly he from daunger was releast,
But loue so faire a Lady, that his life releast?
Long after she from perill was releast:
The Squire of low degree releast
Where falling downe, his challenge he releast:
Ne once for ruth their rigour they releast,
Who nathemore his heauy load releast,
Yet at her speach their rages gan relent,
Perswaded him to ceasse, and her Lord to relent.
And oftentimes he would relent his pace,
And somewhat gan relent his earnest pace,
My raging smart, ne ought my flame relent,
Nor vengeaunce huge relent it selfe at last?
But nothing might relent her hastie flight;
She inly sory was, and gan relent,
Ne euer pittie may relent his malice hard.
Yet pittie often did the gods relent,
Ne did she let dull sleepe once to relent,
But all in vaine; for nought mote him relent,
Yet was soone wonne his malice to relent,
Him forst (maulgre) his fiercenesse to relent,
Yet scarcely once to breath would they relent,
Backe to retire, and somewhat to relent,
Which th'other seeing, gan his course relent,
Relent the rigour of your wrathfull will,
To lend an eare, and softly to relent.
Of breath, their raging rigour to relent,
And being brought in daunger, to relent too late.
Yet though he neuer list to me relent,
Ne rested till she cam without relent
That for great ruth his courage gan relent.
When once he felt his foeman to relent;
Yet he them all withstood, and often made relent.
And maugre all his might, backe to relent:
His hand relented, and the stroke forbore,
The outrage of his furious fit relented.
Of the fraile flesh, relenting to their rage,
Till now at last relenting, she to him was wed.
Ne may by liuing meanes be thence relest:
He bound that pitteous Lady prisoner, now relest,
But Triamond to Cambell it relest,
Bearing that precious relicke in an arke
In which he wont the relickes of his feast,
Which yet with him as relickes did abide
Till ye haue rooted all the relickes out
The litle babe, sweet relickes of his pray;
Tho gathering vp the relicks of his smart
But leaue these relicks of his liuing might,
Of all which ruines there some relicks did remaine.
And there the relicks of the drunken fray,
And Blandamour to Claribell relide.
For either doth on other much relie.
And poore mens boxes of their due reliefe,
And comforted with curteous kind reliefe:
Or that your prowesse can me yield reliefe:
His long endured famine needed more reliefe.
He pluckt from vs all hope of due reliefe,
Well searcht, eftsoones he gan apply reliefe
But doe vouchsafe now to receiue reliefe,
That I may cast to compasse your reliefe,
That but if she did lend her short reliefe,
For death nor daunger from thy dew reliefe
And choisest med'cine for sicke harts reliefe:
Pitty our plaint, and yield vs meet reliefe.
Far from the hoped hauen of reliefe,
Her to restraine, and giue her good reliefe,
And doth for wretched mens reliefe make way;
Without all hope of comfort or reliefe,
Yet if that heauenly grace some good reliefe
Could take no rest, ne would receiue reliefe,
Gaue vnto her great comfort and reliefe,
For that displeasure; and thinke what reliefe
He gan in mind conceiue a fit reliefe
Whose onely ioy was to relieue the needes
Poore prisoners to relieue with gratious ayd,
Seeking the weake oppressed to relieue,
And that late weaker band of chalengers relieued.
Into her eye, which th'heart mote haue relieued,
He mindeth more, how he may be relieued
And of his wonder made religion,
For by the vow of their religion
That neither hath religion nor fay,
Next gan Religion gainst her to impute
Vow'd to the gods: religio[n] held euen theeues in measure.
Regarding nought religion, nor their holy heast.
Religious reuerence doth buriall teene,
In streight obseruaunce of religious vow,
Distaynd with durt and bloud, as relique of the pray.
The broken reliques of their former cruelty.
Go gather vp the reliques of thy race,
The which these reliques sad present vnto mine eie.
And ye the forlorne reliques of his powre,
Her reliques Fulgent hauing gathered,
By these rent reliques, speaking their ill plights?
Gathred the Troian reliques sau'd from flame,
But if some relish of that heauenly lay
As in a swowne: but soone reliu'd againe,
She should not then haue bene reliu'd againe,
But when they saw her now reliu'd againe,
Thought with that sight him much to haue reliued;
And threw in bands, where he till death remaind;
She there remain'd, but with right wary heede,
There he remaind with them right well agreed,
Wherein old dints of deepe wounds did remaine,
Ay wont in desert darknesse to remaine,
His powre is reft, and weaknesse doth remaine.
With fire and brimstone, which for euer shall remaine.
What need of armes, where peace doth ay remaine,
But let me here for aye in peace remaine,
After his foes defeasance did remaine,
Of which a store-house did with her remaine,
Ne Mammon would there let him long remaine,
Great guerdon, well I wote, should you remaine,
Braue moniments remaine, which yet that land enuies.
And after wild, it should to her remaine:
In wretched prison long he did remaine,
And that he victor onely did remaine;
Whiles the dred daunger does behind remaine.
Where both awhile would couered remaine,
That now there do but two of six remaine;
For nought for me but death there doth remaine.
Yet in his frosen members did remaine,
Some thousand yeares so doen they there remaine;
The which he dying left next in remaine
Till so she do, she must in doole remaine,
Full many piteous stories doe remaine,
Of all which ruines there some relicks did remaine.
Where in a maze they both did long remaine,
Giue it to her, for euer to remaine,
Yet did the smart remaine, though he himselfe did flee.
He left him there in languor to remaine,
That any bud thereof doth scarse remaine,
Her person late in perill, did remaine,
In which he long time after did remaine
Oft tossed with his stormes, which therein still remaine.
Did yield, she rather should with him remaine
And looke what surplus did of each remaine,
In which they doe these many yeares remaine,
We are not sure they would so long remaine:
Who all this while behind him did remaine,
With whom whiles he did in the wood remaine,
Vnto the prison, where her hart did thrall remaine.
Which still was wont with Artegall remaine;
That mote remaine for an eternall token
To whom nought else, but bare life doth remaine,
So now all three one sencelesse lumpe remaine,
But euen that which thou sauedst, thine still to remaine?
There he with Belge did a while remaine,
During which time, that he did there remaine,
Of vertue, which with you doth there remaine,
His hope of refuge vsed to remaine.
Of noble Tristram, where it did remaine:
Which we might see after our selues remaine
Or vnderstand, that she in safetie did remaine.
What hope of helpe doth then for vs remaine,
Vpon the rest, that did aliue remaine;
And long while after, whilest him list remaine,
With whom he myndes for euer to remaine,
Where his faire Pastorella did remaine:
They found that life did yet in her remaine:
So did he eeke long after this remaine,
Not purg'd nor heald, behind remained still,
And now he has so long remained there,
Happie this Realme, had it remained euer since.
There all that night remained Britomart,
So there a while they afterwards remained,
Or else remained in most wretched state,
That yet remaines his wide memoriall:
Thus now alone he conquerour remaines;
But still remaines in euerlasting store,
Where he remaines, of all vnsuccour'd and vnsought.
And yet (quoth she) a greater wrong remaines:
Remaines on earth, preseru'd from yron rust
What now is left Clarinda? what remaines,
Where long remaining, he did alwaies striue
And this old woman here remaining beene;
Warnd him not touch, for yet perhaps remaynd
Ne ought in secret from the same remaynd;
They which remaynd, so soone as they perceiu'd,
A seate in Ireland safely to remayne,
To let faire Florimell in bands remayne,
Where many years it afterwards remayned,
Ne of that goodly hew remayned ought,
Thus he long while in thraldome there remayned,
But that some life remayned secretly,
That he remayned in most perilous plight,
Into the chamber, where that Dame remayned
Whylest thus she in these hellish dens remayned,
So that no whit of them remayning one may see.
His late miswandred wayes now to remeasure right.
But this I read, that but if remedee
Ne can my running sore find remedie,
Fond is the feare, that findes no remedie;
She deare besought the Prince of remedie:
Whom she besought to find some remedie:
So left he her withouten remedie.
Find remedie vnsought, which seeking cannot fynd.
In vaine of me ye hope for remedie,
Many a wretch, for want of remedie,
Yet could not remedie her wretched case;
From whence descend all hopelesse remedies:
Emprisond was in chaines remedilesse,
Remedilesse, for aie he doth him hold;
Should be remedilesse, sith none but hee,
And forced to forgoe th'attempt remedilesse.
The cause to weet, and fault to remedy;
For which no reason can find remedy.
Or powre, be hable it to remedy,
To seeke for hearbes, that mote him remedy;
To do him ease, or do him remedy:
That is the whole worlds commune remedy.
Till time for him should remedy prouide,
But all in vaine; for why, no remedy
Can remedy such hurts; such hurts are hellish paine.
And seeking all things meete for remedy.
But she resolu'd no remedy to fynde,
That no man forth might draw, ne no man remedye.
Well could he him remember, sith of late
In those same woods, ye well remember may,
And yet remember well the mightie word,
Indeed he said (if I remember right,)
Marching afore, as ye remember well,
They gan remember of the fowle vpbraide,
Here neede you to remember, how erewhile
Whom (as ye lately mote remember well)
Remember) had her counsels false conspyred,
The deare remembrance of his dying Lord,
And to his fresh remembrance did reuerse
Greeu'd with remembrance of his wicked wayes,
This man of infinite remembrance was,
And put away remembrance of late teene;
Now with remembrance of those spightfull speaches,
Both in remembrance of his friends late harme,
And wiping out remembrance of all ill,
And haue the sterne remembrance wypt away
At the remembrance of their knauerie.
The sad remembrance of her wretched plight.
And sad remembraunce now the Prince amoues,
Ought thy remembraunce, and perpetuall band
Whom for remembraunce of her passed ioy,
To her he made, and many kind remembraunces.
Remembred he, ne car'd for his saufgard,
The warres he well remembred of king Nine,
For he remembred both their infancies:
He then remembred well, that had bene sayd,
Whom he now seeing, her remembred well,
He well remembred, that the same was hee,
The rosie marke, which she remembred well
And his owne health remembring now no more,
She him remercied as the Patrone of her life.
And often treat for pardon and remission
Would ye remit it to some righteous man.
And with a remnant did to sea repaire,
Choking the remnant of his plaintife speach,
Now th'onely remnant of that royall breed,
Or rise against the remnant at their will;
He raft her hatefull head without remorse;
His bloudie rage asswaged with remorse,
Without remorse, or decent funerall:
And in a Dongeon deepe him threw without remorse.
And sharpe Remorse his hart did pricke and nip,
With strokes of mortall steele without remorse,
The noble Guyon mou'd with great remorse,
Drew him through durt and myre without remorse,
Him thereinto he threw without remorse,
That of that feend was rent without remorse:
That her pursewed, saw with great remorse,
That both their speares with pitilesse remorse,
They spoile and rauine without all remorse,
Was toucht with soft remorse and pitty rare;
Who rudely hayld her forth without remorse,
Or made them both one masse withouten more remorse.
Against her brought, to banish all remorse,
With more then needfull naturall remorse,
And brusht, and battred them without remorse,
Neither of other taking pitty nor remorse.
Gaping full wyde, did thinke without remorse
And make one end of him without ruth or remorse.
Searching all lands and each remotest part,
Her faithfull gard remou'd, her hope dismaid,
Which still before him she remou'd away,
That quite his hart from Guendolene remou'd,
Till Romulus renewing it, to Rome remoud.
Ne yet by any meanes remou'd away,
Whose needlesse dread for to remoue away,
And rash misweening doe thy hart remoue:
The whiles to me the treachour did remoue
Those, those thy foes, those warriours far remoue,
And hast he rose, for to remoue aside
That to remoue the same I haue no might:
Some to remoue the scum, as it did rise;
Shall doe vnto her seruice neuer to remoue.
Yet will I not fro mine owne loue remoue,
And yield your heart, whence ye cannot remoue?
No idle charmes so lightly may remoue,
Or loosenesse, that she lightly did remoue.
Yet thousand charmes could not her stedfast heart remoue.
And vse of awfull Maiestie remoue:
A new vnknowen mischiefe did from him remoue.
Which being knit with vertue, neuer will remoue.
Yet nothing could my fixed mind remoue,
Till she drew neare, and then againe remoue;
Yet seeing not how thence he mote remoue,
No words may rate, nor rigour him remoue
May nought at all their setled mindes remoue,
Thought best away me to remoue somewhere
Her constant mynd could not a whit remoue,
And therefore was remoued farre behind,
And had not bene remoued many a day;
Remoued is, th'effect surceaseth still.
But what mishap thus long him fro my selfe remoues?
Remouing her, into his charet brought,
Remounted vp as light as chearefull Larke,
He vp remounted light, and after faind to wend.
Tho hastily remounting to his steed,
Vnto her Coch remounting, home did ride,
On whom remounting, fiercely forth he rode,
Remounts againe into the open aire,
He gan rencounter him in equall race.
Which by that new rencounter he should reare:
To haue rencountred him in equall race;
Rencountred him with so impetuous might,
And him rencountring fierce, reskewd the noble pray.
Who him r'encountring fierce, as hauke in flight,
For anguish great they gan to rend their heare,
And cry, and curse, and raile, and rend her heare,
That would his rightfull rauine rend away:
Which hearing his rash Syre, began to rend
And rend his flesh, and his owne synewes eat.
Yet scratch my sonne, or rend his tender hand?
Did rend the ratling skyes with flames of fouldring heat.
And rend in peeces with his rauenous pawes,
As if the rest some wicked hand did rend,
That from the Daniske Tyrants head shall rend
And many wilde woodmen, which robbe and rend
Whilest deadly torments do her chast brest rend,
And in their flesh a griesly passage rend,
Broke vp the listes, their armes away to rend;
His mighty heart did almost rend in tway,
Right fit to rend the food, on which he fared.
And rend a sunder quite, if he thereto list striue.
And knocke his head, and rend his rugged heares,
That seem'd his shrikes would rend the brasen skie:
She gan to storme, and rage, and rend her gall,
To rend and teare, what so she can oppresse;
As if that it she would in peeces rend,
When he the beast saw ready now to rend
And snatch, and byte, and rend, and tug, and teare;
Out of his breast the very heart haue rended:
Render therefore therein to me my right,
Whose smallest minute lost, no riches render may.
But rudely rending vp his helmet, would
Haue reft away with his sharpe rending clawes:
The sharpnesse of his cruell rending clawes;
The God himselfe rending his golden heare,
Therefore it ought be rendred her without deniall.
She to them runnes in hast, and her haire rends,
And rends her golden locks, and snowy brests embrew.
But rends without regard of person or of time.
Therewith she gan her passion to renew,
With proud foes sight my sorrow to renew:
And fates expired could renew againe,
With like attempt to like end to renew.
Them to renew, I wote, breeds no delight:
Als Vna earnd her traueill to renew.
Renew, as one were borne that very day.
He gan renew the late forbidden banes,
Tho when this breathlesse woxe, that batteil gan renew.
Gathering againe, her Host she did renew,
And to him brought, fresh battell to renew:
For thy hard fortune then thou wouldst renew,
Tho gan she to renew her former smart,
His dreaded head, and the old sparkes renew
He was full wo, and gan his former griefe renew.
